head.title: For Urban Sprawl, Blame Land-Use Regulation

Kenneth T. Jackson (Op-Ed, June 9) quotes Charles E. Merriam of the University of Chicago on his biblical understanding of Lot's wife. While heaven is indeed pictured as a city, Sodom and Gomorrah were cities, too. Lot's problem was that he not only ignored the problems of the city but also contributed to them.

Lot's wife looked back because her children were left behind; for this she died. The image of the heavenly city we can see ahead of us promoted an idealism and an abandonment of the real cities in which we lived.

Mr. Jackson's work would seem to favor the biblical Jeremiah, who called on the faithful to stay and seek the welfare of the city. As for me, am I willing to be Lot's wife: to love and to die for the children of the city?
The writer is an associate professor of sociology at Drew University.
